variant.question: The pitch-up stall behaviour of a swept wing aircraft at subsonic speed is due to the centre of pressure moving:

options.text: Forward when the wing tips stall first, causing the nose to pitch up.
Forward when the trailing edge of the wing roots stall first, causing the nose to pitch up.
Backward when the wing tips stall first causing the nose to pitch down.
Backward when the leading edge of the wing roots stall first, causing the nose to pitch down.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.
Name the C~L~ augmentation devices represented in the annex:

options.text: 1. Variable Camber Flaps; 2. Krueger Flaps; 3. Slats.
1. Krueger Flaps; 2. Slats; 3. Variable Camber Flaps.
1. Krueger Flaps; 2. Variable Camber Flaps; 3. Slats.
1. Slats; 2. Krueger Flaps; 3. Variable Camber Flaps.

variant.question: When flying in icing conditions, ice build-up on an aerofoil will usually occur

options.text: In the area of the stagnation point.
On upper surface from leading to trailing edge.
Close to the centre of pressure.
Close to the trailing edge.

variant.question: The effects of very heavy tropical rain on the aerodynamic characteristics of an aeroplane are

options.text: decrease of CLMAX and increase of drag coefficient.
increase of CLMAX and increase of drag coefficient.
decrease of CLMAX and decrease of drag coefficient.
increase of CLMAX and decrease of drag coefficient.

variant.question: An aircraft has been parked outside overnight, in freezing conditions. The crew decides to depart WITHOUT having the airframe de-iced/anti-iced. What could be the principal danger during take-off?

options.text: Loss of control due to frozen deposits on the wings, which reduce C~LMAX~.
A lower stall speed due to wing contamination and increased drag.
A higher stall speed due to wing contamination and reduced drag.
Uncommanded roll due to frozen deposits on the wings, which increase C~LMAX~.

variant.question: When the trailing-edge flaps are extended, the centre of pressure will move (1) __, producing a pitch (2) __ moment.

options.text: (1) aft; (2) down
(1) aft; (2) up
(1) forward; (2) down
(1) forward; (2) up

variant.question: Which of the following conditions could result in the absence of a stall warning on a jet aeroplane?

options.text: Ice on the wings causing a stall at a lower angle of attack than the normal critical angle of attack.
Ice on the tailplane causing premature boundary layer separation on the stabiliser.
Icing of the pitot tubes causing erroneous speed indications and leading to a stall at a higher indicated speed.
Ice on the fuselage increasing the aeroplane's mass and leading to a stall at a higher speed.

variant.question:
Refer to figures. 
 Considering the three lift augmentation devices in figure 1, which one(s) does the graph in figure 2 represent?

options.text: 3 only
1 only
1 and 3
2 and 3

variant.question: The term 'negative tail stall' describes

options.text: A pitch-down due to an increase in the negative angle of attack of the tailplane, which may occur as the flaps are extended
A pitch-down due to an increase in the negative angle of attack of the tailplane, which may occur as flaps are retracted
A pitch-up due to an increase in the negative angle of attack of the tailplane, which may occur as flaps are extended.
A pitch-up due to an increase in the negative angle of attack of the tailplane, which may occur as flaps are retracted.

variant.question: Icing on the wing can lead to the absence of a stall warning by...

options.text: decreasing the critical angle of attack.
increasing the critical angle of attack.
causing the stall warning device to deflect in the opposite direction thus causing no stall warning.
freezing the device in place preventing it from moving at high angles of attack.

variant.question: High lift devices are used...

options.text: from takeoff until cruise.
to increase the lift during an approach.
during cruise.
during approach to reduce the flight speed.

variant.question:
A light aeroplane has flown in icing conditions and accumulated ice on the horizontal stabiliser. 
 If the pilot does nothing to account for the ice, then during the landing flare, the aircraft might suffer a tail stall and:

options.text: A nose-down pitch causing the nose wheel to contact the runway first.
A gentle nose-down pitch that is easily controllable with the elevator.
A nose-up pitch leading to a premature wing stall and a hard landing on the main wheels.
A nose-down pitch that may cause an undershoot of the runway.

variant.question:
Which statement is correct?

1.  A stick pusher activates at a higher angle of attack than a stick shaker.

2. A stick shaker prevents the pilot from increasing the angle of attack further.

options.text: I is correct, II is incorrect.
I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is correct.

variant.question:
Which statement is correct?

1.  A stick pusher activates at a lower angle of attack than a stick shaker.

2. A stick shaker prevents the pilot from increasing the angle of attack further.

options.text: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
I is correct, II is correct.
I is incorrect, II is correct.
I is correct, II is incorrect.

variant.question: Where is icing most likely to form on an aircrafts profile?

options.text: On an area where the stagnation point is located.
On the upper surface of the aerofoil, from leading edge to the trailing edge.
On an area where the centre of pressure is located.
Around the trailing edge.

variant.question: When high lift devices deploy asymmetrically:

options.text: Asymmetric trailing edge devices give a large and possibly uncontrollable rolling moment.
Asymmetric leading edge devices give a large and possibly uncontrollable rolling moment
The major problem with asymmetric  trailing edge devices is uncontrollable yaw.
Asymmetric leading edge devices give a large and possibly uncontrollable yawing moment.

variant.question: Ice contamination on a wing will cause (1) _____ in stall speed and (2) _____ critical angle of attack.

options.text: (1) an increase; (2) a decrease
(1) an increase; (2) no change
(1) a decrease; (2) an increase
(1) no change; (2) a decrease

variant.question: Ice on the wings:

options.text: Decreases CLMax
Increases CLMax

Can either increase or decrease CLMax depending on the
ice build up above and below the wing

Has no effect on CLMax, it just increases the stall
speed

variant.question: An aircraft is covered with de-icing fluid during winter operation. Which statement is true?

options.text: Stall speed will increase
Stall speed will decrease
Stall speed is not affected
Stall speed will decrease once at cruise level

variant.question: Shock stall

options.text: occurs when the lift coefficient, as a function of Mach number, reaches its maximum value.
results from flow separation at the underside of the aerofoil.
occurs as soon as Mcrit is exceeded.
results from flow separation behind the bow wave.

variant.question: Shock stall is:

options.text: separation of the boundary layer behind the shock wave.
separation of the flow at high angles of attack and at high Mach numbers.
separation of the flow behind the bow wave.
separation of the flow at the trailing edge of the wing at high Mach numbers.

variant.question: The input to a stick shaker comes from:

options.text:
Angle of attack, and sometimes the rate of change in
angle of attack.
The angle of incidence.

The airspeed, and sometimes the rate of change in
airspeed.
The angle of attack only.

variant.question: The pitch up tendency of an aeroplane with swept back wings during a stall is caused by the:

options.text: forward movement of the centre of pressure.
aft movement of the centre of pressure.
forward movement of the centre of gravity.
aft movement of the centre of gravity.

variant.question: Extension of trailing-edge flaps (1) _____ downwash. In case of ice contamination, the risk of premature stabiliser stall (2) ______.

options.text: (1) increases; (2) increases
(1) decreases; (2) decreases
(1) decreases; (1) increases
(1) increases; (2) decreases

variant.question: You notice ice on the tailplane and the tailplane stalls when you flare, what will happen?

options.text: Nose goes down and nose wheel touches ground first
Aircraft pitch is not affected but achieving usual flare attitude will be difficult
Nose rises and main wheels touch first
The aircraft will balloon

variant.question: A stick pusher:

options.text: pushes the elevator control forward when a specified value of angle of attack is exceeded.
pushes the elevator control forward prior to stick shaker activation.
vibrates the elevator control.
pushes the elevator control to avoid a stall at a negative load factor.

variant.question: The type of stall that has the largest associated angle of attack is:

options.text: a deep stall.
a low speed stall.
an accelerated stall.
a shock stall.

variant.question: The type of stall that has the largest associated angle of attack is:

options.text: Deep stall.
High speed stall (shock stall).
Accelerated stall.
Low speed stall.

variant.question: On a swept wing aeroplane at low airspeed, the pitch up phenomenon:

options.text: is caused by wingtip stall.
never occurs, since a swept wing is a remedy to pitch up.
is caused by boundary layer fences mounted on the wings.
is caused by extension of trailing edge lift augmentation devices.

variant.question: Which statement about negative tail stall is correct?

options.text: When negative tail stall occurs, the aeroplane will show an uncontrollable pitch-down moment.
Negative tail stall is a stall of the tailplane when the aerodynamic force is in upward direction.
When negative tail stall occurs, the aeroplane will show an uncontrollable pitch-up moment.
Negative tail stall is a stall of the fin with a negative sideslip angle -nose pointing to the right of the relative airflow-.

variant.question: Which statement about negative tail stall is correct?

options.text: When negative tail stall occurs, the aeroplane will show an uncontrollable pitch-down moment.
Negative tail stall is a stall of the tailplane when the aerodynamic force is in upward direction.
When negative tail stall occurs, the aeroplane will show an uncontrollable pitch-up moment.
Negative tail stall is a stall of the fin with a negative sideslip angle (nose pointing to the right of the relative airflow).

variant.question: Which statement about negative tail stall is correct?

options.text: When negative tail stall occurs, the aeroplane will show an uncontrollable pitchdown moment.
When negative tail stall occurs, the aeroplane will show an uncontrollable pitch-up moment.
Negative tail stall is a stall of the tailplane when the aerodynamic force is in upward direction.
Negative tail stall is a stall of the fin with a negative sideslip angle (nose pointing to the right of the relative airflow).

variant.question: Which combination of design features is known to be responsible for deep stall?

options.text: Swept-back wings and a T-tail.
Swept-back wings and wing-mounted engines.
Straight wings and a T-tail.
Straight wings and aft, fuselage-mounted engines.

variant.question: You notice ice on the tailplane and, as a result, the tailplane stalls in the landing flare. How can you expect the aeroplane to behave?

options.text: Nose goes down and nose wheel touches ground first.
Nose goes up and the aeroplane may enter a full stall.
The aeroplane will behave normally due to ground effect.
Nose goes down and may tailstrike.

variant.question: The pitch up effect of an aeroplane with swept-back wing in a stall is due to the:

options.text: wing tip stalling first.
wing root stalling first.
aft movement of the centre of gravity.
forward movement of the centre of gravity.

variant.question: Negative tail stall is:

options.text: a sudden reduction in the downward aerodynamic force on the tailplane.
flow reversal on the fin leading to flow re-attachment.
a typical aerodynamic problem for canards.
flow separation at the rear of the lower surface of the wing.

variant.question: An aeroplane is established on final approach descending through 1000 ft when the pilot realizes that the aeroplane is about to enter an area of heavy tropical rain. The pilot must consider that the stalling...

options.text: speed increase due to the C~LMAX~ reduction because of water distorting the shape of the airfoil and the airflow pattern.
speed increase due to compressibility effects appearing earlier than normal because of the concentration of water on the wings.
angle of attack decrease due to the apparent decrease of the load factor from the heavy downpour of rain.
angle of attack decreases due to the associated gusts from the heavy downpour of rain.

variant.question: What happens to the stall speed in a steep turn?

options.text: It increases because the vertical component of lift is reduced.
It is constant if enough thrust is added to compensate for the additional drag.
It reduces due to the angle of pitch required to maintain level flight.
It remains unchanged due to the critical angle of attack.

variant.question: The pitch-up stall behaviour of a swept wing aircraft is due to the centre of pressure moving...

options.text: forward when the wing tips stall first.
forward when the wing roots stall first.
backward when the wing tips stall first.
backward when the wing roots stall first.

variant.question: Low speed pitch up can be caused by the

options.text: outward drift of the boundary layer on a swept-back wing.
wing tip vortices on high aspect ratio wings.
dihedral effect.
boundary layer separation at the wing tip of a forward swept wing.

variant.question: Which of the following is not listed in CS 25 as a reliable indicator of the stall?

options.text: High nose attitude
The nose pitching down without control input.
Lateral instability
Severe buffeting

variant.question: It is possible for the stabiliser to stall prematurely due to ice contamination. In this case...

options.text: the aeroplane will pitch down.
lateral control of the aeroplane will be greatly affected.
longitudinal control of the aeroplane will NOT be affected.
the aeroplane will pitch up.

variant.question: Which of the following factors might result in the absence of a stall warning on a commercial jet transport aeroplane?

options.text: Ice on the wings causing a stall at a lower angle of attack than the normal critical angle of attack.
Ice on the fuselage increasing the aeroplane's mass and leading to a stall at a higher speed.
Ice on the tailplane causing premature boundary layer separation on the stabiliser.
Icing of the pitot tubes causing erroneous speed indications and leading to a stall at a higher indicated speed.

variant.question: Shock stall occurs:

options.text: Because of flow separation, at any angle of attack
Only at high angles of attack
Only at high Mach Numbers
Due to flow separation on the underside of the aerofoil

variant.question: The function of the stick pusher is:

options.text: to activate and push the stick forward at or beyond a certain value of angle of attack.
to vibrate the controls.
to activate and push the stick forward prior to stick shaker.
to pull the stick, to avoid a high speed stall.

variant.question: An aeroplane where its CG is located forward of its Centre of Pressure suffers a premature tailplane stall as a result of ice contamination. Provided the wings do NOT stall, the outcome will be a(n)...

options.text: nose down pitch upset, the magnitude of which will depend on the location of the aeroplanes CG.
nose up pitch upset, the magnitude of which will depend on the location of the aeroplanes CG.
uncommanded nose down pitch that will be accompanied by the activation of the stall warning system.
uncommanded nose up pitch that will be accompanied by the activation of the stall warning system.

variant.question: Low speed pitch up is caused by the:

options.text: spanwise flow on a swept back wing.
spanwise flow on a swept forward wing.
wing tip vortex.
Mach trim system.

variant.question: Icing on the wing can lead to the absence of stall warning by:

options.text: Decreasing the critical angle of attack at which a stall occurs
Ice on the leading edge of the wing.
Ice forming in the pitot tube, affecting the ASI.
Freezing the ailerons, which increases critical alpha.

variant.question: A pitch up could be caused by:

options.text: forward movement of the centre of pressure.
lateral movement of the centre of gravity.
a reduction in varying loads due to G.
forward movement of the centre of gravity.

variant.question: Q feel systems need inputs from:

options.text: Pitot and static pressures
Pitot and dynamic pressures
Dynamic and static pressures
Ambient and dynamic pressures

variant.question: What can be said about a T-tail configuration and a low stabiliser position?

options.text: A T-Tail is more stabilising because it is less affected by downwash from the wing.
A T-tail is less stabilising because it is less affected by downwash from the wing.
A T-tail is more stabilising because it is more affected by downwash from the wing.
A T-tail is less stabilising because it is more affected by downwash from the wing.

variant.question: A T-Tail has...

options.text: more stabilizing effect than a low tail, due to receiving less downwash.
more stabilizing effect than a low tail, due to receiving more downwash.
less stabilizing effect than a low tail, due to receiving more downwash.
less stabilizing effect than a low tail, due to receiving less downwash.
